H0.text: The Moon to revolve once determines the length of one day on Earth.

H1.text: The length of one day on Earth is determined by how long it takes the Moon to rotate once.

H2.text: Earth to rotate once determines the length of one day on Earth.

H3.text: Earth to revolve once determines the length of one day on Earth.

A4.text: Earth's rotation period relative to the International Celestial Reference Frame, called its stellar day by the International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service (IERS), is 86 164.098 903 691 seconds of mean solar time (UT1) (23h 56m 4.098903691s, 0.99726966323716 mean solar days).

A5.text: Over millions of years, Earth's rotation has been slowed significantly by tidal acceleration through gravitational interactions with the Moon.
